Title.evidence: Intrathecal Oxytocin for Postoperative Recovery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Participants.evidence: 98 participants undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive intrathecal oxytocin (100 μg) or saline

Objective.evidence: This trial assessed whether intrathecal oxytocin accelerates recovery from pain and disability following major surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the modelled pain trajectory from hospital discharge over 8 weeks.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with concealed allocation.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Ninety patients were analysed (oxytocin: n=44; saline: n=46) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome showed no significant difference in pain trajectory between groups (intercept: −0.1, 95% CI: −0.8 to 0.6, p=0.746; slope: 0.1, 95% CI: 0 to 0.2, p=0.057).

Harms.evidence: No study drug-related adverse effects were observed.

Funding.evidence: The study was terminated early due to lack of funding.
